text:
If you're in the early
years of your career,

you've probably given little
thought to your own retirement,

except maybe giving in
to your parents' nagging

about starting an
IRA for yourself.

But if you think retirement
is all about the money,

and my research team
found that's what

comes to mind when most younger
people think about retirement,
you need to think again.

Retiring well is also about
identity, relationships,

and structuring a life
that will work for you.

You're likely to have 20, 30, or
even more healthy years of life
after you retire.

And beginning to think about
it now, along with that IRA,

can set you up to make the
most of those precious years.
First, identity.

Yes, you need to throw yourself
into your work right now,

but is that the only
identity you're developing?
Next, relationships.

Think about the
friends and family

you will want to grow old with,
and nurture those relationships.
Finally, life structure.

Do your main activities
focus on career?

Or are you developing
passions outside work

that you might enjoy even more
after your working days are
done?

Build the foundation now for a
beautiful retirement life later.

If you're in the
middle of your career,

you might be thinking a lot more
about your parents' retirement

or the retirement of
your older colleagues

than you're thinking
about your own.

What can you do if that person
won't consider retiring,

even if they seem increasingly
exhausted or beaten down
by their work?

If you have a trusting
relationship with them,

you could invite a
conversation about what

they foresee for themselves
over the next five or 10 years.

My research team had
the people in our study

draw a life map showing the
key activities, relationships,

groups, organizations, and
places in their current life.

And some of those people
drew what they envisioned
for their retirement life, too.

This could be a fun and
enlightening exercise

to encourage your parent
or colleague to do.

Heck, you could even
do it with them,

drawing your own current life
and your ideal retirement life.

As you help them talk through
which elements of their life

seem to be working for
them and which don't really

suit the person
they are now, they

could begin to see the
attractive new possibilities

that retiring would
open up for them.

Are you thinking
about retirement

because you're approaching
the end of your career

or maybe you've
recently retired?

What most people don't realize
is that retiring takes work.

The work can be fun, but it
does take attention and effort.

I'm not talking about
financial planning here,

but your psychological
well-being and the way

you restructure your
life when you retire.

My research team
discovered four tasks

that you need to
work through if you

want a smooth transition to
a satisfying retirement life.

Each task has its
own challenges.

First, deciding when and how to
retire where the big challenge

is developing
awareness of the person

you are now and how well your
working life fits that person.

Second, detaching
psychologically

from your work, where the
big challenge is figuring out

how strongly you
identify with your work

and whether you have the
tools to happily let it go.

Third, building a
provisional retirement life,

where the big challenge is
exploring and experimenting

with new activities,
relationships,
and places to spend your time.

Fourth, consolidating
a retirement life that

works for you, where the big
challenge is figuring out

which of those experimental
elements fits the person

you are and seems viable
for the foreseeable future.
